author: sky.cactus
content: <@273808422753796097> There are cases where that won't change the amount paid by the user.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, bribe is 1 and fee cap is 100 and current base fee is over fee cap.  No matter what you increase the bribe by you will pay fee cap as soon as the base fee drops low enough for your transaction to be included.

author: sky.cactus
content: This tells us that we cannot rely on only increasing the bribe as being a "costly operation" for the user (to disincentive RBF operations).

author: sky.cactus
content: If only the fee cap changes, miners don't have any incentive to use one transaction over another if they can include either.  Also, it is possible that the base fee may move from "neither are valid" to "both are valid" such that they both have the same effective gas price at mine time.

author: sky.cactus
content: (large downward moves in base fee can happen when there are multiple empty blocks mined in a row due to randomly short block times)

author: sky.cactus
content: Regarding "clients refuse transactions when base fee is higher than fee cap", it is possible that two clients will disagree with the current base fee (different views of the chain), which means one client can send a transaction that another will reject.  Is this going to cause problems with devp2p?  I think <@!194432762315407360> has mentioned in the past that devp2p currently doesn't have any dependency on current chain state.

author: abdel.stark
content: My opinion is that we can handle that on a higher layer. For example in tx_pool validateTx method  https://github.com/vulcanize/go-ethereum/blob/716864deba26d2afea6b3cb62eeb573613d6b86b/core/tx_pool.go#L519. The second parameter indicates if the transaction is local or come from the p2p layer. You can apply the rule only for remote transactions and without doing any penalty to the peer. You only ignore the transaction if the feecap is lower than chain head base fee (with a tolerance delta based on the max denominator of 1 / 8), i.e if transaction can't be included within the next X blocks then i reject it without impacting peer reputation.

author: abdel.stark
content: You can also update the eviction mechanism to take into account that the base fee moves. In addition to the life time of the transaction you can apply a rule about how far the feecap is from the base fee

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!301186049323958275> were you also suggesting to not propagate the transaction through p2p or only rejecting incoming txs ?

author: sky.cactus
content: Both.  The idea is that if the transaction's `fee_cap < latest_block.base_fee * constant` you would not accept it from a peer, and you would not send it to a peer.
